statement.tex: %text If \[ x = \tan\left( \frac{1}{a}\log y \right) \], then show that \[ \qquad (1+x^2)\cdot\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} + (2x-a)\cdot\frac{dy}{dx} = 0\] %
\\ %text Which of the following would give us a $(1+x^2)$ term that we see in \[ \qquad (1+x^2)\cdot\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} + (2x-a)\cdot\frac{dy}{dx} = 0?\] %
\\ %text Given that \[ \tan^{-1}x = \frac{1}{a}\log y \], which of the following is true? %

reason.tex:
%text If the \underline\text{$(1+x^2)$ term} caught your eye, then ask yourself, \underline\text{where have I seen it before}?
Turns out that \[\frac{d}{dx}\tan^{-1} x = \frac{1}{1+x^2} \].
Notice also that % \begin{align} x &= \tan\left( \frac{1}{a}\log y \right) \implies\tan^{-1}x = \frac{1}{a}\log y \end{align} \\ %text
\underline\text{It looks like the dots are connecting!} %

%text It is a just a little algebra in this step.
% \begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{ay}{1+x^2} &\implies \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} = \frac{d}{dx}\left( \frac{ay}{1+x^2} \right) \\ \therefore\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &= a\cdot\underbrace{\left[\frac{(1+x^2)\cdot y' - y\cdot 2x}{(1+x^2)^2}\right]}_{\text{Quotient Rule}}\\ &= \frac{a\cdot y'}{1+x^2} - \underbrace{\frac{ay}{1+x^2}}_{\text{what is this?}}\cdot\frac{2x}{1+x^2}\\ &= \frac{a\cdot y'}{1+x^2} - y'\cdot \frac{2x}{1+x^2} \\ &= \frac{y'}{1+x^2}\cdot (a-2x) \\ \therefore (1+x^2)\cdot\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &+ (2x-a)\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \end{align}
